I am not yet in a position to identify which school might be grant aided until the scheme becomes operational.

Qst.Quest: if he will outline (1) the special pay awards which are due to teachers in 1992 and (2) the pay rises which are due after the Programme for Economic and Social Progress.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mr. Davern) Noel Davern
Speaker.P: With regard to (1), report No. 17 of the Arbitration Board for Teachers recommended increases in the common basic salary scale and allowances for teachers in primary, secondary, vocational, community and comprehensive schools. The increases recommended range from 8 per cent to 12 per cent and are payable under the terms of clause 3.4 of the elaboration of clause 3 of the 1987 agreement on pay in the public service which provides for phasing as follows: 40 per cent of the increases with effect from 1 May 1991, 30 per cent of the increases with effect from 1 March 1992 and 30 per cent of the increases with effect from 1 September 1992.
The first phase has been paid with effect from 1 May 1991.
With regard to (2) the pay agreement which forms part of the Programme for Economic and Social Progress as it applies to teachers provides for an increase of 3 per cent of basic pay in 1992.

Qst.Quest: if his attention has been drawn to the fact that approximately 5,000 students will be seriously disadvantaged because of the decision by the National Council for Educational Awards to recognise the ordinary leaving certificate alternative mathematics course as a minimum entry requirement for 13 out of the approximate 200 courses at Regional Technical College/DIT level, while universities recognise the same course for matriculation purposes; if he will outline the action he proposes to take to rectify this situation; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mr. Davern) Noel Davern
Speaker.P: The alternative maths syllabus is a recognised leaving certificate subject for entry to NCEA validated courses for which mathematics is not prescribed as a compulsory eligibility requirement. Points are allocated for alternative maths in the same manner as for other subjects.
However, where mathematics is a compulsory eligibility requirement, the alternative maths course is not deemed to meet this requirement.

Alternative mathematics will count for matriculation purposes but will not be accepted as a substitute for mathematics in courses where mathematics is an entry requirement. Points are not awarded for alternative mathematics in the university sector.

Qst.Quest: if having regard to the urgency for the provision of the two extra classrooms at Ballygunner national school in County Waterford he will outline when construction will start.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mr. Davern) Noel Davern
Speaker.P: My Department had placed the contract for the proposed extension to Ballygunner national school, County Waterford earlier this year but the contractor subsequently withdrew his tender. As a consequence my Department have had to consider other contractors for the project and the procedures in this regard are well advanced.
A decision will be conveyed to the school authorities at the earliest possible date and I will advise the Deputy of developments.

Qst.Quest: the reason for the delay in sanctioning the package of new programmes for leaving certificate higher level, two ordinary level and senior certificate which were submitted earlier this year to his Department by the National Council for Curriculum Assessment; having regard to the fact that officials from his Department were on the course committee which approved the programmes; when sanction will be forthcoming; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mr. Davern) Noel Davern
Speaker.P: Recommendations on the structure, format and programmes relating to the curriculum at senior cycle have been submitted to my Department by the National Council for Curriculum and Assessment.
These recommendations and the views of my Department on them will be set out in the Green Paper on Education in order to afford the opportunity to concerned interests to comment on them.
